text:
In J.R.R. Tolkien's iconic Lord of the Rings series, power is a pervasive and potent force that shapes the destiny of Middle-earth. The struggle for power is a recurring theme throughout the narrative, to the extent that it can be argued that power is, itself a character. 

On one hand, the corrupting influence of power is epitomized by the primary antagonist, Sauron. His relentless pursuit of domination stems from an insatiable lust for control,  and his unyielding ambition to dominate all of Middle-earth. This malevolent force drives him to enslave and destroy entire populations, simply to satiate his own ego and reinforce his grasp on power. Conversely, the Free Peoples of Middle-earth, led by the Fellowship, are fueled by their desire to resist this encroaching darkness and preserve freedom and autonomy.

On the other hand, the benevolent exercise of power is exemplified by characters such as Aragorn (Strider) and Galadriel. Their authority is tempered with wisdom, compassion, and restraint. They wield their respective forms of power – Aragorn as King Elessar, and Galadriel as the Lady of Lothlórien – not to oppress or aggrandize themselves but to safeguard and serve others.
